english: Miserable; pitiable; wretched (often with a humiliating or pathetic nuance). Na-adjective: 惨めな.
japanese_example: <ruby>負<rt>ま</rt></ruby>けて<ruby>惨<rt>みじ</rt></ruby>めな<ruby>気持<rt>きも</rt></ruby>ちになった。
english_example: I lost and felt miserable.

english: A hedge; a living fence made of shrubs/trees used as a boundary.
japanese_example: <ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>前<rt>まえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>生垣<rt>いけがき</rt></ruby>がある。
english_example: There is a hedge in front of the house.

english: To stare at; to gaze at intently (sustained, focused looking).
japanese_example: その<ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>顔<rt>かお</rt></ruby>をずっと<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>つめていた。
english_example: The child kept staring at my face.

english: Lonely; lonesome; can also describe a desolate/forlorn atmosphere.
japanese_example: <ruby>夜<rt>よる</rt></ruby>は<ruby>一人<rt>ひとり</rt></ruby>だと<ruby>寂<rt>さび</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: At night, I feel lonely when I’m alone.

japanese: 今までになく寂しかった
hiragana: いままでになくさびしかった
english: Was lonelier than ever before; “今までになく/今までにない” means “unprecedentedly; more than ever.”
japanese_example: <ruby>引<rt>ひ</rt></ruby>っ<ruby>越<rt>こ</rt></ruby>してから、<ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>までになく<ruby>寂<rt>さび</rt></ruby>しかった。
english_example: After moving, I was lonelier than ever before.

english: More than that; rather than that; used to shift focus to something more important or relevant.
japanese_example: それよりも、<ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>く<ruby>帰<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>ろう。
english_example: More importantly, let’s go home soon.

english: A close/best friend; stronger than 友達, implying deep trust and intimacy.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>親友<rt>しんゆう</rt></ruby>です。
english_example: He is my best friend.

english: And yet; despite that; connects a prior situation to an unexpected/contradictory result.
japanese_example: <ruby>一生懸命<rt>いっしょうけんめい</rt></ruby><ruby>勉強<rt>べんきょう</rt></ruby>した。それなのに、<ruby>試験<rt>しけん</rt></ruby>に<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ちた。
english_example: I studied hard. And yet, I failed the exam.

english: Two people (counter for people); special reading (not ににん).
japanese_example: <ruby>二人<rt>ふたり</rt></ruby>で<ruby>映画<rt>えいが</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>に<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: The two of us went to see a movie.

japanese: 二人はハリーに会いたいとも思ってないらしい
hiragana: ふたりははりーにあいたいともおもってないらしい
english: It seems the two don’t even want to meet Harry. 〜たいとも思ってない emphasizes “don’t even want to…,” and らしい indicates a judgment based on indirect information.
japanese_example: <ruby>二人<rt>ふたり</rt></ruby>はハリーに<ruby>会<rt>あ</rt></ruby>いたいとも<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>ってないらしい。
english_example: It seems the two don’t even want to meet Harry.

english: Both (of two); どちら is “which (one of two),” and adding も commonly yields “both.”
japanese_example: コーヒーもお<ruby>茶<rt>ちゃ</rt></ruby>も、どちらも<ruby>好<rt>す</rt></ruby>きです。
english_example: I like both coffee and tea.

hiragana: なつやすみにはいって
english: Since summer vacation started; upon entering summer vacation. Often used as 〜に入ってから to mean “from the start of ….”
japanese_example: <ruby>夏休<rt>なつやす</rt></ruby>みに<ruby>入<rt>はい</rt></ruby>ってから、ずっと<ruby>忙<rt>いそが</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: Since summer vacation started, I’ve been busy the whole time.

english: An overnight stay (noun), often implying staying somewhere for the night.
japanese_example: <ruby>今夜<rt>こんや</rt></ruby>は<ruby>泊<rt>と</rt></ruby>まりにする。
english_example: I’ll stay overnight tonight.

english: To come to stay overnight. Pattern: Vます-stem + に来る = “come in order to do V.”
japanese_example: <ruby>友達<rt>ともだち</rt></ruby>がうちに<ruby>泊<rt>と</rt></ruby>まりに<ruby>来<rt>く</rt></ruby>る。
english_example: A friend is coming to stay overnight at my place.

english: Come! (imperative of 来る). Strong/direct command; a softer alternative is 来て.
japanese_example: こっちへ<ruby>来<rt>こ</rt></ruby>い！
english_example: Come here!

english: Casual quoting: “(someone) said ‘…’.” って functions like と as an informal quotation marker.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は「<ruby>明日<rt>あした</rt></ruby><ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>く」って<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He said, “I’m going tomorrow.”

english: An invitation (noun), typically inviting someone to an event or to visit (distinct from hospitality, もてなし).
japanese_example: パーティーの<ruby>招待<rt>しょうたい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>受<rt>う</rt></ruby>けた。
english_example: I received an invitation to a party.

english: To invite (someone). Common pattern: 人を招待する.
japanese_example: <ruby>友達<rt>ともだち</rt></ruby>を<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>招待<rt>しょうたい</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I invited my friend to my home.

english: Was supposed to (but did not happen). はず expresses an expected outcome based on plan/logic, and はずだった often implies the reality differed.
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>休<rt>やす</rt></ruby>みのはずだったのに、<ruby>働<rt>はたら</rt></ruby>くことになった。
english_example: I was supposed to have today off, but I ended up working.

english: To send; to mail. Common objects include 手紙 and メール.
japanese_example: <ruby>母<rt>はは</rt></ruby>にプレゼントを<ruby>送<rt>おく</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I sent a present to my mother.

english: Volitional of 送る: “I’ll send (it)” or “let’s send (it),” expressing intention or a proposal.
japanese_example: じゃあ、メールを<ruby>送<rt>おく</rt></ruby>ろう。
english_example: Okay, let’s send an email.

english: Volitional + か: “Shall I send it?” (an offer) or “Should I send it?” depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>資料<rt>しりょう</rt></ruby>、<ruby>送<rt>おく</rt></ruby>ろうか？
english_example: Shall I send you the materials?

english: Causative of 持つ: to make/let someone hold or carry something.
japanese_example: <ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>どもに<ruby>水<rt>みず</rt></ruby>を<ruby>持<rt>も</rt></ruby>たせた。
english_example: I made the child carry the water.

hiragana: なんどもなんどもかんがえた
english: I thought about it over and over; repeating 何度も intensifies the sense of repeated action.
japanese_example: そのことを<ruby>何度<rt>なんど</rt></ruby>も<ruby>何度<rt>なんど</rt></ruby>も<ruby>考<rt>かんが</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: I thought about it again and again.
